stem: The nurse is providing education for a client starting a GLP-1 receptor agonist (e.g., semaglutide) for type 2 diabetes and weight management. Which information should the nurse include in the teaching?

options.text: Administer the injection once daily at the same time each day.
Discontinue the medication if you experience a single episode of vomiting.
Report any new or worsening depression or suicidal thoughts immediately.
Contact the healthcare provider for severe, persistent abdominal pain.
Expect mild nausea and decreased appetite during the first few weeks.
Rotate the injection site among the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm.

rationale.correct: GLP-1 agonists carry a risk for neuropsychiatric events, so reporting mood changes (Option A) is essential. Mild GI upset (Option C) is a common side effect during the dose-escalation phase. Severe, persistent abdominal pain (Option D) is a hallmark sign of pancreatitis, a known serious complication. Rotation of injection sites (Option F) is required for all subcutaneous medications to prevent lipodystrophy.
rationale.incorrect: Many GLP-1 agonists (like Ozempic/Semaglutide) are administered *once weekly*, not daily (Option B). While vomiting is a side effect, patients should not discontinue high-alert medications after a single episode without medical consultation (Option E); dose adjustments are usually preferred.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: In this specific NGN scenario, "Administer the injection once daily at the same time each day." is incorrect as it introduces clinical risk or deviates from standard triage logic.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: Choosing "Discontinue the medication if you experience a single episode of vomiting." represents a misinterpretation of the gathered cues or a failure to prioritize physiological needs.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: "Report any new or worsening depression or suicidal thoughts immediately." represents a critical metric that must be monitored to evaluate the effectiveness of the current medical plan.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: "Contact the healthcare provider for severe, persistent abdominal pain." represents a critical metric that must be monitored to evaluate the effectiveness of the current medical plan.

answerBreakdown.label: E
answerBreakdown.content: "Expect mild nausea and decreased appetite during the first few weeks." represents a critical metric that must be monitored to evaluate the effectiveness of the current medical plan.

answerBreakdown.label: F
answerBreakdown.content: "Rotate the injection site among the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm." represents a critical metric that must be monitored to evaluate the effectiveness of the current medical plan.

clinicalPearls: GLP-1 agonists slow gastric emptying, which can affect the absorption of other oral medications.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Pay close attention to the specific drug class. GLP-1s are famous for their weekly dosing, which is a major selling point for adherence.

mnemonic.title: G-L-P
mnemonic.expansion: Gastric slowing, Look for Pancreatitis, Psych monitoring.

reviewUnits.heading: Incretin Mimetics
reviewUnits.body: GLP-1 agonists mimic natural hormones to stimulate insulin and slow gastric emptying. Nursing priorities: GI tolerance, site rotation, and monitoring for pancreatitis.
